adjourned.heading: Hearing didn't take place
content: The hearing for your appeal didn’t take place as scheduled. We’ve sent you a letter explaining why, which you should receive by {{adjournedLetterReceivedByDate|formatDate}}.

We’ll now set a new date for your hearing. You don’t need to do anything. Unfortunately we can’t say how long it will take to book but it may be some time. It will depend on how busy the hearing venues are.

appealReceived.heading: Appeal received
appealReceived.content: We’ve told DWP that you’ve appealed against their decision. They should respond before {{dwpResponseDate|formatDate}}. We’ll contact you and explain the next steps when they’ve replied.

closed.heading: Appeal closed
content: Your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal is now closed.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

dormant.heading: Hearing took place
content: A hearing for your {{benefitType|acronym}} appeal took place on {{date|formatDate}} and a decision was made. You should receive the decision by post within 7 working days of the hearing.
We can’t publish the decision online or tell you over the phone. This is to protect your personal information.

dwpRespond.heading: DWP response
content: DWP have written a response to your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal. They should have sent you a copy in the post.

We now need to book your hearing. You don’t need to do anything. We’ll contact you again when we have a date for your hearing. Unfortunately we can’t say how long it will take to book but it may be some time. It will depend on how busy the hearing venues are.

dwpRespondOverdue.heading: DWP response overdue
content: DWP were due to respond to your appeal by {{dwpResponseDate|formatDate}}. We’ve written to them again to remind them. We’ll let you know when they respond.

evidenceReceived.heading: Evidence received
evidenceReceived.content: The evidence you sent was received by us on {{date|formatDate}}.

hearing.heading: Hearing took place
content: A hearing for your {{benefitType|acronym}} appeal took place on {{date|formatDate}} and a decision was made. You should receive the decision by post within 7 working days of the hearing.
We can’t publish the decision online or tell you over the phone. This is to protect your personal information.

hearingBooked.heading: Hearing booked
hearingBooked.content: A hearing has been booked for your appeal.

lapsedRevised.heading: Change of decision
content: DWP have told us they changed their decision on your entitlement to {{benefitType|acronym}} in your favour. We’ve therefore closed this appeal. If you don’t agree with their new decision you can start a new appeal.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

newHearingBooked.heading: New hearing booked
newHearingBooked.content: A new hearing has been booked for your appeal.

pastHearingBooked.heading: Still booking a hearing
pastHearingBooked.content: We’re still trying to find a suitable time for your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal. We’ll contact you as soon as we’ve scheduled it. We apologise for any inconvenience this may cause you.

postponed.heading: Hearing postponed
content: The hearing for your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal has been postponed and will now take place on a different day.

We’ll now book a new hearing for your appeal. You don’t need to do anything. Unfortunately we can’t say how long it will take to book but it may be some time. It will depend on how busy the hearing venues are.

withdrawn.heading: Appeal withdrawn
content: You told us you wanted to withdraw your appeal so we’ve closed it.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

appeal.happened: Appeal received. This step is complete.

dwpRespond.due: DWP respond to your appeal. This has not happened yet.
dwpRespond.happened: DWP respond to your appeal. This step is complete.

hearingBooked.due: Hearing booked. This has not happened yet.
hearingBooked.happened: Hearing booked. This step is complete.

hearing.due: Hearing for your appeal. This has not happened yet.
hearing.happened: Hearing for your appeal. This step is complete

claimExpenses.title: Claiming expenses to attend your hearing
claimExpenses.content: You may be able to claim back some of the money you spend on attending your hearing.

content: You should use public transport where possible. Keep your travel tickets and bring them with you to your hearing. You’ll be given a claim form to fill out by the tribunal clerk.

If you have a health condition or disability which means you can’t get yourself to the hearing then you might be able to claim for a taxi. You’ll need to get authorisation first by phoning 0300 123 1142.

evidence.notReceived: If you have any evidence to support your appeal, you should send it as soon as possible. This so there's time to read it before your hearing.
evidence.received: If you have any more evidence to support your appeal, you should send it as soon as possible. This is so there's time to read it before your hearing.

provide.title: Providing evidence to support your appeal
provide.content: Evidence is anything that supports your appeal. It could be medical records, letters or documents. What you say at the hearing is also evidence. It all helps the tribunal understand the facts of your appeal.

medicalEvidence.heading: Medical evidence
content: This is the most important form of evidence. Medical evidence helps the tribunal understand your condition and how it affects your life.

As a patient, you have a right to a copy of your medical records. You’ll need to ask your doctor for them as early as possible in your appeal. Only get records going back 2 years from the time you made your appeal.

You might have other medical evidence which isn’t included in your medical records. For example a letter from a consultant, physiotherapist or mental health worker. Submit these too, if they are relevant to your condition at the time you received your decision from DWP.

You’ll need to send evidence to the tribunal as early as possible. If you submit evidence too close to your hearing, it could be delayed to a different day because there hasn’t been enough time to review it.
Please be aware your doctor or consultant may charge you for your medical records. We can’t reimburse you for this.

oralEvidence.heading: Oral evidence
content: What you or anyone else says on your behalf at the hearing is called oral evidence. If you have a carer or someone who supports you in your home, you might want to invite them to come and tell the tribunal about your condition.
You should check the person is willing to talk at your hearing and available on the day.

whereToSendEvidence.heading: Where to send your evidence
content: Post evidence to the following address, clearly marked with your appeal reference number:
address: Liverpool Social Security and Child Support Tribunal

register.title: Register for notifications
register.content: Receive reminders and notifications to keep you updated on the progress of your appeal
register.question: How would you like to receive notifications?

manage.title: What do you want to do?
manage.visuallyHidden: What do you want to do?

stop.title: You’ll stop receiving email updates and reminders about your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal.

stopConfirmation.title: You’ve stopped email notifications
stopConfirmation.content: You won’t receive any more emails about your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal.
stopConfirmation.exitFeedbackSurveyLink: feedback to help us improve this service.

addressChange.title: Your new email address
addressChange.visuallyHidden: What do you want to do?

errors.title: There are errors on the page.

addressChangeConfirmed.title: Emails about your {{benefitType|acronym}} benefit appeal will now be sent to
addressChangeConfirmed.content: We’ve sent a confirmation email to that address. Check it in a few minutes.

errors.selectAnOptionField: You have not selected an option. Select an option.
errors.emptyStringEmailField: You have not entered your email address. Enter your email address.
errors.notValidField: The email address you’ve entered is invalid. Check it and enter it again.
errors.noMatchField: Your email addresses don’t match. Check and enter them again.

details.title: What to expect at your hearing

expectations.title: What to expect at your hearing
expectations.link: Find out what your hearing is going to be like
expectations.content: Your hearing is an opportunity for you to explain your appeal and get an impartial decision on your entitlement to {{benefitType|fullDescription}}. The tribunal is independent and will consider both sides of the appeal.

whenYouArrive.heading: When you arrive
whenYouArrive.content: You’ll be greeted by a tribunal clerk. They’ll take care of you at the hearing venue and answer any questions you have.

caption.pip: A PIP benefit appeal with a judge, doctor and disability expert
caption.esa: An ESA hearing with a judge and a doctor

imageAlt.pip: A tribunal hearing with 5 people, dressed informally, sat around a table.
imageAlt.esa: A tribunal hearing with 4 people, dressed informally, sat around a table.

theHearingRoom.heading: The hearing room
theHearingRoom.content: The tribunal clerk will take you into the hearing room. The judge and medical expert will be sitting at a table. You’ll be invited to sit opposite them. If you have someone to support you or to give evidence, they’ll sit next to you.

peopleAtHearing.heading: The people at your hearing
content: The tribunal is made up of a judge and a medical expert who will make an impartial decision on your appeal. They are both independent from DWP.
The judge runs the hearing and will explain how it works. They’ll also take notes of what is said during the hearing.
The medical expert is there to give their medical opinion on your appeal.

dwp.heading: DWP
content: A representative from DWP might be there. They are not on the panel and are there to speak on behalf of DWP. They won’t be the person who made the decision about your entitlement to {{benefitType|acronym}}.

duringHearing.heading: During your hearing
content: The tribunal panel members will ask you some straightforward questions. They’re trying to understand how your condition affects your life. This is your opportunity to explain your side of the appeal. They will consider everything you tell them.

Sometimes the tribunal panel will need more evidence to help them make a decision. It’s important that you submit all your evidence well before the hearing so they have time to review it. Otherwise they may have to postpone the hearing to a different day.

gettingDecision.heading: Getting a decision
content: After you’ve answered all the questions you’ll be asked to wait outside while the tribunal discusses your appeal. You’ll then be asked back into the room to be told the decision.
The judge will explain whether you’re entitled to {{benefitType|acronym}} and if so, at what level.
Sometimes the tribunal may need more time to make a decision. If that happens the decision about your appeal will be posted to you.

hearingDetails.interpretersBookedByUs: Only interpreters booked by us can translate for you at the hearing.
hearingDetails.incorrect: If you can't attend, call us on 0300 123 1142

pleaseNote.heading: Please note
content: You can bring people to support you at your hearing. For example family, friends or a support worker. There will be a limit to the number of people you can take into the hearing room because of space.
Children are allowed in the waiting area but not in the hearing room. You’ll need to bring someone to supervise them while you’re in the hearing.
Bring all documents relating to your appeal to the hearing. For example letters or evidence we or DWP have sent you.

validateSurname.title: Enter your last name
validateSurname.heading: Enter your last name - Appeal a benefit decision - GOV.UK

surname.hint: This is to check it's your appeal and protect your personal information

errors.emptyStringHeading: Enter your last name to continue
errors.notValidHeading: You have entered an invalid last name. Enter your last name in full
errors.noMatch: Your last name does not match the last name on the appeal you are trying to access. Enter your last name again.

trackYourAppeal.title: Track your benefit appeal
trackYourAppeal.hint: You can find this on any letter you’ve received about your benefit appeal.

common.availableInAnotherLanguage: This page is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

cookiePolicy.titleHead: Cookie Policy - Appeal a benefit decision - GOV.UK

banner.text: GOV.UK uses cookies to make the site simpler.

usedInService.title: How cookies are used in this service
usesList: measure how you use the service so it can be improved
remember the notifications you’ve seen so that you’re not shown them again
temporarily store the answers you give

howAreTheyUsed.title: Cookies used to measure website usage
howAreTheyUsed.description: We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use this service. We do this to help make sure the service is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements, for example improving site search.
infoList: the pages you visit
how long you spend on each page
how you got to the service
what you click on while you’re visiting the service
howAreTheyUsed.googleShare: We allow Google to use or share this data. Find out more about how they use this information in the

optOut.access: if you do not want Google to have access to your information.

howAreTheyUsed.googleCookies: Google Analytics sets the following cookies:

items.name: _ga
items.purpose: This helps us count how many people visit the service by tracking if you’ve visited before

introMessage.title: Cookies used to turn our introductory message off
introMessage.description: You may see a welcome message when you first visit the service. We’ll store a cookie so that your computer knows not to show this message again.

items.name: seen_cookie_message
items.purpose: Saves a message to let us know that you’ve seen our cookie message

sessionCookie.title: Cookies used to store the answers you’ve given during your visit (known as a ‘session’)
sessionCookie.description: Session cookies are stored on your computer as you browse a website, and let the website know what you’ve seen and done so far. These are temporary cookies and are automatically deleted after you leave the website.

items.name: ARRAffinity
items.purpose: To know which internal IP a request should be routed to.

contactUs.title: Contact us
contactUs.description: For help and support with your appeal call:

error500.title: Page could not be found
error500.heading: Sorry, we're experiencing technical difficulties
content: Please try again in a few minutes.
Or, if you want an update on your appeal you can call 0300 123 1142.

error404.title: We're experiencing technical difficulties
error404.heading: Sorry, this page could not be found
content: Check that you’ve entered the correct web address.
If you want an update on your appeal you can call 0300 123 1142.

termsAndConditions.titleHead: Terms and conditions - Appeal a benefit decision - GOV.UK
termsAndConditions.title: Terms and conditions

termsAndConditions.termsOfUse: By using this service you’re agreeing to the following terms of use. This includes the

whoWeAre.title: Who we are
whoWeAre.managedBy: This service is managed by Her Majesty’s Courts and Tribunals Service.
whoWeAre.changeInLaw: You should check these terms and conditions regularly. We may update them at any time without notice. If you continue to use this service after the terms and conditions have changed, you are deemed to have agreed to the changes.

informationProvided.title: Information provided by this service
informationProvided.support: This service provides information to support your claim or application. We cannot give legal advice on individual cases.
informationProvided.questions: You should answer the questions in the service based on your circumstances and seek legal advice if you need it.

dataStored.title: Sharing and storing data
dataStored.privacy: explains where your data is stored, and who it is shared with.
dataStored.cookie: explains how this service uses and stores cookies.

laws.title: Laws applying to this service
laws.use: Your use of this service and any dispute arising from its use will be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of England and Wales, including but not limited to the:

responsibleUse.title: How to use this service responsibly
responsibleUse.aware: There are risks in using a shared computer (for example, in a library) to access this service. It’s your responsibility to be aware of these risks and to avoid using any computer which may leave your personal information accessible to others. You’re responsible if you choose to leave a computer unprotected while using this service.
responsibleUse.precautions: You should take your own precautions to ensure that the way you access this service does not expose you to the risk of:
risks: other forms of interference which may damage your computer system
responsibleUse.mustNot: You must not misuse this service by knowingly introducing viruses, trojans, worms, logic bombs or other material which is malicious or technologically harmful. You must not attempt to gain unauthorised access to this service, the system on which it is stored, or any server, computer or database connected to it. You must not attack this site using a denial-of-service attack or a distributed denial-of-service attack.

sensitiveInfo.title: Entering personally sensitive information
sensitiveInfo.freeText: This online service contains several free-text fields in which you may choose to enter information which is personally sensitive.
sensitiveInfo.enter: If you enter information about your:
infoList: religious beliefs
sexual orientation or sex life
racial or ethnic origins
political opinions
religious or philosophical beliefs
trade union membership
genetic data or biometric data
health data
sensitiveInfo.consent: You give us your consent to processing this information for the purpose of dealing with your application.
sensitiveInfo.moreInfo: For more information about how we collect and store your personal data, see the privacy policy

disclaimer.title: Disclaimer
disclaimer.upToDate: While we make every effort to keep information up to date, we don’t provide any guarantees, conditions or warranties that it will be:
disclaimer.publish: We don’t publish advice. You should get professional or specialist advice before doing anything on the basis of the information in the service.
disclaimer.loss: We’re not liable for any loss or damage that may come from using this service. This includes:
damages: any direct, indirect or consequential losses
any loss or damage caused by civil wrongs (‘tort’, including negligence), breach of contract or otherwise
the use of this service, GOV.UK and any websites that are linked to or from it
the inability to use this service, GOV.UK and any websites that are linked to or from it
disclaimer.applies: This applies if the loss or damage was foreseeable, arose in the normal course of things or you advised us that it might happen.
disclaimer.includes: This includes (but isn’t limited to) the loss of your:
losses: intangible property, including loss, corruption or damage to data or any computer system
disclaimer.liable: We may still be liable for:
liabilities: death or personal injury arising from our negligence
any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited under applicable law

titleHead: Privacy Policy - Appeal a benefit decision - GOV.UK

privacy.title: Privacy policy
privacy.description: This privacy policy explains why we collect your personal data and what we do with it. It also explains your rights and how to enforce them.

manages.title: Who manages this service
manages.managedBy: This service is managed by HM Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS), which is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ).

data.controller: The MoJ is known as the data controller for data protection purposes. The
data.process: explains how the MoJ processes personal data.

manages.responsible: As part of the MoJ, HMCTS is responsible for deciding how your personal data is used and for protecting the personal data you provide.

moreInfo.service: More information about using this service is in the

whyWeCollect.title: Why we collect your personal data
whyWeCollect.collect: We collect your personal data to:
whyWeCollect.staffUseData: Our staff use your personal data to process your claim or application. They work in the UK and your data is stored in the UK.

personalData.title: Types of personal data we collect
personalData.collect: The personal data we collect includes:
collectList: your name, address and contact details
your email and password (if you create an account)
other personal information you provide in your claim or application

more.data: Some services collect more personal data. Find out more about the
more.link: personal data that is collected by the service you are using.

usingYourData.title: Using your data
usingYourData.account: As part of your claim you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You will be able to use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.
usingYourData.permission: We may ask for your permission to use your email address to send you emails using GOV.UK Notify. This system processes emails only within the European Economic Area until the point where emails are handed over to the email provider you use.

cookies.collect: to collect data that tells us about how you’re using this service, including:

dataList: if you open an email from us or click on a link in an email
your computer, phone or tablet’s IP address
the region or town where you are using your computer, phone or tablet

storingData.title: Storing your data
storingData.dataProvided: When you make your claim or application we store the data you have provided. This is stored in the UK. The amount of time that your data is kept for depends on the service that you are using.

findOut.link: how long your personal data is stored by the service you are using.

shareDate.title: Sharing your data
shareDate.involved: While processing your claim or application, another government department, agency or organisation might be involved and we may share your data with them.
shareDate.contact: If you contact us and ask for help with the service you are using, your personal data may be shared with the Good Things Foundation. This is a company who we have partnered with to offer face to face support.
shareDate.share: In some circumstances we may share your data for example, to prevent or detect crime, or to produce anonymised statistics.

google.used: We use Google Analytics to collect data about how a website is used. This anonymous data is shared with Google. Find out about this in our

internationally.title: Storing and sharing your data internationally
internationally.outsideUK: Sometimes we need to send your personal information outside of the UK. When we do this we comply with data protection law.

yourRights.title: Your rights
questions: to see the personal data that we hold on you
to have the personal data corrected
to have the personal data removed or deleted (this will depend on the circumstances, for example if you decide not to continue your claim or application)
that access to the personal data is restricted (for example, you can ask to have your data stored for longer and not automatically deleted)
yourRights.seeData: If you want to see the personal data that we hold on you, you can:

form.controller: Your request goes to the MoJ as data controller.

yourRights.write: write to us: Disclosure Team, Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
yourRights.moreInfo: You can ask for more information about:
infoList: agreements we have on sharing information with other organisations
when we are allowed to pass on personal information without telling you
our instructions to staff on how to collect, use or delete your personal information
how we check that the information we hold is accurate and up-to-date
yourRights.contactOfficer: You can contact the MoJ data protection officer, by:
contactList: writing to us: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ

complain.title: How to complain

complaints.personalData: if you want to complain about how we've handled your personal data.

complain.write: Write to: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ

commissioner.canAlso: You can also complain to the
commissioner.notSatisifed: if you’re not satisfied with our response or believe we are not processing your personal data lawfully.

appealBenefit.title: Using the Appeal a benefit decision service

personalData.title: The personal data we need
personalData.weAskFor: When you use the appeal a benefit decision service we ask for:
yourDetails: your email or mobile phone number
information from the Mandatory Reconsideration Notice
information on any support you need for a hearing, if you attend one
information on your availability for a hearing, if you attend one
personalData.rep: If you have a representative, we will ask for:
personalData.onBehalf: If you are appointee, you will need to provide information about the person who you are appealing on behalf of, including:

notifications.title: Receiving notifications
notifications.receive: As part of your appeal we’ll ask if you want to receive text message and email notifications to keep you updated with your appeal.
notifications.cancel: You can cancel text messages by following the steps mentioned in the text message, and you can cancel emails by following the steps mentioned in the emails.

updates.rep: If you have asked for your named representative to receive updates on your appeal, then we will share your data with them. If you want your representative to stop receiving notifications then you need to

storing.title: Storing and sharing your data
storing.shared: Your data will be shared with the government department that made the decision you are appealing against. For example, the Department for Work and Pensions or HM Revenue and Customs. This is so that department can respond to your appeal.

after.title: After you submit your information
after.deleted: The information you submit will be deleted 2 years after the tribunal have issued their decision and the last update has been made to your appeal.
after.noDecision: If the tribunal doesn’t make a decision about your appeal (for example, it is withdrawn, or both parties agree) then the information you provide will be deleted 2 years after the appeal has been closed and the last update made.
after.complaint: If you make a complaint against the tribunal then information about the appeal is stored for 3 years after the last update on the complaint.

after.deleted: The information you submit will be deleted 2 years after the tribunal have issued their decision and the last update has been made to your appeal.
after.noDecision: If the tribunal doesn’t make a decision about your appeal (for example, it is withdrawn, or both parties agree) then the information you provide will be deleted 2 years after the appeal has been closed and the last update made.
after.complaint: If you make a complaint against the tribunal then information about the appeal is stored for 3 years after the last update on the complaint.
